Dear Ms. Gordy:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 9/13/21.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and MISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please indicate why the previous CAP did not work and what changes will
be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following: (d) Current immunizations
for each child as required by section 5111 of 1978 PA 368,
MCL333.5111…
One of eight foster care files did not have an immunization record. Nor was there
documentation of parent refusal of immunizations.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/15/2019 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/8/2019
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(2) An agency shall have documentation from the medical or

File one: A medical exam was documented in the file from 7/20/20. However, there
was no accompanying documentation from the physician’s office. Dental exams

accompanying documentation from the dentist’s office.

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
 Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
 Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
 Beginning at age 14, semi-annual transition meetings
must Occur once every 180-calendar days to discuss a
youth’s Permanency goal and identify supportive adults.
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following:
 Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
checking it for accuracy, identifying areas needing follow-
up, and recording the outcome data.
 Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
to all participants (in person and by phone), legal parents,
and casework supervisor. These documents must also
be uploaded into MISACWIS.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Foster Home Licensing Application- The agency reported sending an
application to families with the renewal notification letter at least 60 days prior
to license expiration. However, the renewal letter did not indicate the
application was enclosed. While application timeliness could be verified by
the date the application was signed, the agency was advised to state in the
renewal letter that an application was enclosed.
 Family Team Meetings- Several FTM 1105 reports were noted to have blank
signature pages. Caseworkers documented phone/video attendance of
participants in MiSACWIS. The agency was advised to document this
information on the FTM 1105 report as well.
 Two foster care files did not have documentation of education for the current
school year. As the school only began a few weeks ago, TA was offered and
the agency was advised to enter current data at the beginning of each school
year to ensure the information in MiSACWIS is up to date throughout the
year.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
Renewal evaluation dated 7/16/2020 determined 31 licensing, MISEP and contract
violations. A CAP was approved on 8/6/20. Overall, the agency appears to be
following their CAP, as evidenced by improvement in several previously cited areas.
During this review, there were 17 violations, including 11 repeat violations. However,
the occurrence of each violation has decreased from the 2020 review. The agency
will adjust areas from previous CAPs to continue to increase compliance in the
coming year.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Annual Assessment dated 7/20/21 was reviewed. The
assessment was completed by the previous CA, before leaving the agency in August
2021. The CA assessment noted increased compliance in areas previously
addressed in CAPs from 2019 and 2020. CAP reviews, team meetings, and regular
supervision have assisted the agency in addressing areas of improvement and
reviewing policy/procedure changes as they occur. As reflected in the assessment
and discussed while on-site with the new CA, the agency had to adjust over the past
year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Video conferencing, staff working remotely,
11

and utilizing new technology such as DocuSign has helped the agency continue to
do business as needed, while keeping staff and clients safe. In addition, the CA
reported that a higher-than-normal retention rate over the past year has also helped
the agency maintain stability. The CA identified areas of improvement to focus on
over the next year, which is consistent with areas identified by DCWL in this review.
Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. Both staff reported that supervisors and
administration are very supportive. The agency is a great place to work and very
flexible with their schedules. Staff reported administration cares about their well-
being during the pandemic and reminds staff to have self-care. Staff reported no
concerns or areas the agency could improve upon.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
